coffeeNet.title: CoffeeNet
coffeeNet.desc: What started as a toy project evolved into a really great demonstration of the full suite of topics in data science. CoffeeNet takes images and sensor data off a raspberry pi to monitor and predict a coffee pot’s state and provide analytics and predictions to the office via a slick front-end application. Credit to Mark Hoffman and Valentino Constantinous for laying most of the groundwork for this project.

portfolio.title: Portfolio Site
portfolio.desc: This page itself has undergone quite a few iterations. As it was originally conceived as a way to learn more web development principles, it was first built with raw html and css, then later redesigned and rebuilt with the Bootstrap framework and more styling. The site is now being retooled with React components and a more modern, concise style. Stay tuned :)

jc2.title: Gaming Analytics Research
jc2.desc: Working with a team of researchers in the UK and Germany, a small group of us from MSiA pioneered novel algorithms and approaches to analyzing player behavior in open-world games like Just Cause 2. We utilize bipartite-tensor factorization and various predictive models and clustering techniques to predict churn and profile player archetypes.

albumAI.title: Album AI
albumAI.desc: Can artificial intelligence decipher abstract album art to determine the likely genre of an album? This project attempts to answer that question with cutting edge deep learning techniques in computer vision. To accompany the project, I built out an application to serve the predictions and gather human input against which our models were benchmarked.

instacart.title: Instacart Profiler
instacart.desc: Focusing primarily on infrastructure and model deployment, this project leverages the vast InstaCart dataset to profile users and predict likely orders. The application is containerized with Docker and deployed with AWS resources like EC2, S3, and RDS to serve predictions based on user input.

enova.title: Enova Data Smackdown
enova.desc: This exciting hackathon posed an interesting scenario in which were the head of a house-flipping group with a set amount of money to spend on acquisition and renovation. Using a wealth of real estate data, we were able to find the most lucrative investment opportunities and optimize our group’s profit.

abc.title: ABC Hackathon
abc.desc: In this quick hackathon, ABC challenged us to analyze their massive datasets around customer financing and credit risk across many branches. Our work helped evaluate loan effectiveness in various geographies and refine existing ideas on acceptable credit risk.

bpForecast.title: BP Forecasting Tools
bpForecast.desc: My team and I built out forecasting tools and predictive models in an enterprise cloud environment (Palantir) using PySpark to drive big data analytics. Our tools enabled the operations teams at BP to understand index price trends, forecast risk, and predict bid outcomes based on market conditions and contract structure.

venmo.title: Venmo Network Analysis
venmo.desc: To gain familiarity with big data tools like spark, HBase, Hive, MapReduce, and others, I tackled this and other projects with fellow MSiA students. This project in particular uses some social network analysis and graph theory concepts to analyze Venmo transaction data.

energyVis.title: Global Energy Visualizations
energyVis.desc: An experiment in visualization and data-driven storytelling, this project attempts to capture public interest around the use of energy across the world over the years. The site has been designed as an interactive experience that draws the user in with a compelling story, and then invites people to explore on their own with engaging visualization tools.

eloKaggle.title: Kaggle ELO Hack
eloKaggle.desc: This Kaggle competition provided merchant and customer data from a ELO, a Brazilian credit company. We evaluated thousands of data features and investigated hundreds of model architectures to arrive at a set of predictions on future spending. Our team was less concerned about a final MSE, and more interested in an exhaustive comparison of modeling techniques - a goal which proved worthwhile.

bcg.title: BCG Hackathon
bcg.desc: Another student and I analyzed some rich data on energy usage among a Spanish power company’s customer base. We built predictive models to forecast customer behavior and guide business decisions such as promotional offerings, customer segmentation, and variable pricing.

dsTools.title: Data Science Toolbox
dsTools.desc: This was conceived as a one-stop-shop for examples, references, and notes for future data science projects. The repository includes many snippets from past projects, toy examples borrowed from various tutorials, and some of my condensed notes from grad school.

campsite.title: Campsite Finder
campsite.desc: Through a Hackathon at DePaul university, I worked with a couple strangers to help build an application that would connect users to available camping sites across the US. I setup most of the backend infrastructure and logic and built in a social component that allows users to save favorite campsites, share suggestions with others, and comment on their experiences.

skills.title: Skills Based Demand
skills.desc: During one of my first projects in analytics I worked with several other students and Greenwich HR to quantify and forecast demand for jobs in the IT space based on associated skills. We ended up developing some novel approaches to measuring job demand and packaged all this in a slick user application to encourage exploration. Big thanks to classmate JD Cook for getting most of the dashboard put together.

bookstore.title: Bookstore Offer Analysis
bookstore.desc: A deep analysis of sales and advertising data from a German bookstore allowed for predictive modeling of customer behavior in response to future promotions. This analysis was performed with an ensemble of models produced in R to optimize short and long-term profit fo the bookstore.

rms.title: Roster Management System
rms.desc: Built a robust web application for roster management among student organizations. Users can be granted various privileges to manage rosters, update member information, and process updates in bulk via file upload. Note: this application was commissioned as contract work, but went unfinished due to loss of funding.

healthModel.title: User Health Model
healthModel.desc: Sourced clickstream data and account information to build out user profiles for a SaaS company to monitor customer activity. Used these profiles to analyze and predict churn across the customer base and to inform CRM specialists on how to structure workshops, reach out to users, and prioritize visits.

sim-u.title: Sim-University
sim-u.desc: As part of my first Hackathon, I helped build out a Zoo-Tycoon-style game that gave the player the keys to a university which they would manage and develop. This was my first exposure to Python and I have to thank Daniel Schon for providing the idea and a lot of the code during this project and for helping bring me along.

filtra.title: E-Commerce from Scratch
filtra.desc: Developed an e-commerce solution for a large filter manufacturer. This was my first exposure to web development and allowed me to learn to work with tools like MongoDB, Angular, Express, Node.js, and Stripe. I mainly worked on the backend for this application, but also built out the frontend for carts and the checkout process.

studyIt.title: StudyIt Mobile App
studyIt.desc: To prepare for an internship opportunity, I dreamed up this side project (my first independent programming project). This React Native mobile app allowed a user to easily upload a spreadsheet of questions and answers and then quiz themselves over the material from their phone.

crawlMapper.title: Crawl Mapper
crawlMapper.desc: As part of a CS course in my undergrad, this project took data from sensors on crawling babies and turned the points into a dashboard that visualized the baby moving through space. The entire project is implemented in Java with a focus on structures and abstractions.
